newsitem.title: UK: Patten tells China to relax over Hong Kong.
newsitem.headline: Patten tells China to relax over Hong Kong.

text.p: Hong Kong can remain one of the world's great cities in the next century under Chinese rule, the territory's British governor Chris Patten said on Thursday.
"All China needs to do is relax about Hong Kong," Patten told a conference of Scottish business leaders in Edinburgh.
"The fact of Hong Kong's present success is not in question. The question is, will it continue after the return to Chinese sovereignty in the middle of next year.
"We've done our best to give Hong Kong the best possible chance for the future. It would take spectacular incompetence to destroy that success," he said.
Patten said doubts remained about the future but Britain was doing everything possible to preserve Hong Kong's way of life.
"Independence was never an option," he said. "We are handing a free society to a society that has a different concept of freedom."
Patten told the conference, entitled "Hong Kong, 1997 and beyond", that important guarantees were given in the Joint Declaration in which Britain and China agreed on the handover.
They were not just guarantees for the survival of capitalism in Hong Kong but of the context in which it flourished, he said.
"We've taken them seriously and tried to make them stick."
He said there had been disagreements with China on such things as human rights and the rule of law but these had not damaged Hong Kong's economic progress.
The chairman of Hong Kong's stock exchange said China could be trusted to nurture financial markets after the territory was handed over to Beijing next year.
"China has extensive commercial interests in Hong Kong...it can be trusted to behave pragmatically," Edgar Cheng Wai-Kin told the conference.
But he said pro-democracy groups could disrupt harmony after China takes over from Britain at midnight on June 30 and warned his compatriots not to antagonise Beijing.
"China needs strong government. Hong Kong must also have strong government...the control of existing pressure groups is one of the key tests for the future," Cheng said.
Hong Kong has the sixth largest foreign exchange market in the world and its stock market is the eighth largest -- the biggest in Asia after Japan.
The task was to maintain the integrity of existing regulatory institutions, now run by Hong Kong people who would be staying on after the handover, Cheng said.
